facts.text: Naunit Lal appeared for the petitioners

anchor.surface_text: Naunit Lal, for the petitioners. The respondent did number appear. ORDER This application purports to be one under 0. XLV, rr. 2 and 5 of the Supreme Court Rules and companytains the following prayers - to direct the respondents to furnish security for delivering possession of the lands in dispute and for payment of mesne profits and companyts which the petitioners might get in appeal to restrain the respondents from transferring the lands in dispute or creating any charge on the said lands pending the decision of the appeal in this Honble Court to send for the record of the case and get the record printed under the supervision of this Honble Court to order an early hearing of the case.

facts.text: Respondent did not appear

facts.text: Respondents are decree holders who obtained possession of the land in suit in execution of the decree in their favour

anchor.surface_text: The respondents-decree holders have obtained possession of the land in suit, in execution of the decree in their favour. The petitioners did number take any action under 0. XLV, r. 13  2 , Civil Procedure Code, at the time the respondents-decree holders applied for execution. If they had applied to the High Court for the stay of execution, the High Court companyld have either allowed execution on taking security from the respondents for the due performance of any order which this Court might have made on the appeal or might have stayed the execution of the decree on taking security from the petitioners-appellants for the due per- formance of the decree appealed from or of any decree or order which this Court might make on the appeal.

facts.text: Petitioners did not take any action under Order XLV rule 13(2) CPC when respondents applied for execution

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners did number take any action under 0. XLV, r. 13  2 , Civil Procedure Code, at the time the respondents-decree holders applied for execution. If they had applied to the High Court for the stay of execution, the High Court companyld have either allowed execution on taking security from the respondents for the due performance of any order which this Court might have made on the appeal or might have stayed the execution of the decree on taking security from the petitioners-appellants for the due per- formance of the decree appealed from or of any decree or order which this Court might make on the appeal. The question arises whether, after the decree has been executed and the decree-holders have been put in possession by the Court, this Court can put the respondents-decree holders to terms and direct them to furnish security for their delivering possession of the land in dispute and for payment of mesne profits, if the appeal succeeds and whether the Court can restrain the respondents-decree holders from transferring the lands in dispute, pending the decision of the appeal in this Court.

facts.text: Decree appealed from was executed unconditionally as no directions given by High Court

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from sub-r. 1 that unless the Court otherwise directs the decree has to be unconditionally executed. Naturally, directions of the Court must be given before the execution of the decree. If numberdirections are given, the execution of the decree is unconditional, which means that the decree-holder executes the decree without any companyditions attached and, after executing the decree, can deal with the property he has obtained on such execution, in such manner as the law allows him to deal with it.

arguments.claim: Sadar Dewani Adalat competent to require decree-holder to furnish security pending appeal even after execution issued, as per precedents

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Naunit Lal, for the petitioners, has referred us to some cases and to the provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure, in this connection. Reliance is chiefly placed on the case of Mst. Jariutool-Butool v. Mst. Hoseinee Begum 1 which was followed by the Madras High Court in Narayanan Chetti v. Arunachallam Chetti 2 and by the Bombay High Court in Khushaldas Gokuldas v. Chimanlal Kalidas 3 in a case which came before it after the enactment of the Code in 1908.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: engal Regulation V of 1798, sections V and VI. Section 11 of the Bengal Regulation XVI of 1797 provided for persons desirous of appealing from a judgm

arguments.court_reasoning: Precedents based on old Bengal Regulations which differ; those required security upfront or allowed correction of default, unlike CPC O.XLV r.13 which mandates unconditional execution unless directed before

arguments.claim: Under O. XLV r.13(1) CPC, decree appealed from shall be unconditionally executed unless Court otherwise directs before execution

anchor.surface_text: Order XLV, C.P.C., deals with matters in connection with appeals to this Court. Rule 13 deals with the powers of the Court whose decree is under appeal, during the pendency of that appeal, and reads 13. (1) Notwithstanding the grant of a certificate for the admission of any appeal, the decree appealed from shall be unconditionally executed, unless the Court otherwise directs.

arguments.claim: Directions under O. XLV r.13(2) CPC can only be given on special cause shown when dealing with execution application, before execution, not after

anchor.surface_text: The Court may, if it thinks fit, on special cause shown by any party interested in the suit, or otherwise appearing to the Court,- a impound any movable property in dispute or any part thereof, or b allow the decree appealed from to be executed, taking such security from the respondent, as the Court thinks fit for the due performance of any order which the Supreme Court may make on the appeal, or c stay the execution of the decree appealed from, taking such security from the appellant as the Court thinks fit for the due performance of the decree appealed from, or of any decree or order which the Supreme Court may make on the appeal, or d place any party seeking the assistance of the Court under such conditions or give such other direction respecting the subject- matter of the appeal, as it thinks fit, by the appointment of a receiver or otherwise.

arguments.claim: O. XLV r.14 CPC applies only to increase inadequate existing security, not to demand fresh security post unconditional execution

anchor.surface_text: Rule 14 provides for the increase of the security furnished by either party when it is found to be inadequate. If the appellant fails to deposit the additional security ordered, the decree is to be executed and if it is the decree-holder respondent who defaults to furnish the additional security, the court can stay the further execution of the decree and restore the parties to the position in which they respectively were when the security which appeared inadequate was furnished or give such directions respecting the subject-matter of the appeal as it thought fit.

arguments.claim: No provision in CPC or SCR allows Supreme Court to direct security or restraints post-execution of decree

anchor.surface_text: Order XX, r.1, Supreme Court Rules however deals with the question of staying the execution of a decree and reads The filing of an appeal shall not prevent execution of the decree or order appealed against but the Court, may, subject to such terms and conditions as it may think fit to impose, order a stay of execution of the decree or order, or order a stay of proceedings, in any case under appeal to the Court.

arguments.claim: Inherent powers under O. XLV r.5 SCR not exercisable to impose post-execution security or restraints, as statutory scheme exhaustive and would encourage judgment-debtor default and abuse of process

anchor.surface_text: Order XLV, r. 5, of the Supreme Court Rules, simply provides that the inherent powers of this Court, to make necessary orders to meet the ends of justice or to prevent abuse of the process of the Court, are not affected by the rules. ... To exercise any such inherent power would be not for the prevention of the abuse of the process of the Court but may be to encourage it inasmuch as the judgment-debtor who had been in default in taking necessary action at the proper time would be encouraged to ask for that action after the execution of the decree and during the pendency of the appeal in this Court.

arguments.claim: Precedents relied on by petitioner under old Bengal Regulations not applicable to CPC O. XLV as regulations required upfront security unlike CPC's unconditional execution rule

anchor.surface_text: In the Privy Council case, the Privy Council expressed the opinion that the Sadar Dewani Adalat was competent to require the decree- holder to furnish the security or otherwise to provide for the protection and security of the property in question pending the appeal, notwithstanding that execution had issued before the appeal was admitted. ... We find nothing in these provisions which empowered the Court of Sadar Dewani Adalat to demand security from the respondent decree holders or to restrain them from transferring any property over which they had obtained possession in execution of their decree before an appeal was taken to the Privy Council.

arguments.claim: Petitioners' interests protected without security or restraints as transfers by respondents pending appeal subject to lis pendens and mesne profits recoverable if appeal succeeds

anchor.surface_text: We may note that the failure of the appellants to obtain such reliefs from this Court need not necessarily prejudice them in case they succeed in the appeal. Any transfers of the property in suit made by the respondents- decree holders during the pendency of the appeal would be subject to the law of lis pendens.

holdings.text: We are therefore of opinion that the aforesaid reliefs cannot be granted after the decree-holders had been put in possession of the property in suit in due execution of their decree.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the aforesaid reliefs cannot be granted after the decree-holders had been put in possession of the property in suit in due execution of their decree.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme under Order XLV r.13 CPC mandates unconditional execution unless directed before; no provision for post-execution security or restraints; precedents distinguished; inherent powers not exercisable as would encourage abuse of process.

holdings.text: Notwithstanding the grant of a certificate for the admission of any appeal, the decree appealed from shall be unconditionally executed, unless the Court otherwise directs.

anchor.surface_text: 13. (1) Notwithstanding the grant of a certificate for the admission of any appeal, the decree appealed from shall be unconditionally executed, unless the Court otherwise directs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation of Order XLV r.13(1) CPC; directions must precede execution.

holdings.text: It is clear from sub-r. 1 that unless the Court otherwise directs the decree has to be unconditionally executed. Naturally, directions of the Court must be given before the execution of the decree.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from sub-r. 1 that unless the Court otherwise directs the decree has to be unconditionally executed. Naturally, directions of the Court must be given before the execution of the decree. If nodirections are given, the execution of the decree is unconditional,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical application of r.13(1): absence of prior directions means unconditional execution allowing decree-holder free dealing with property.

holdings.text: The sub-rule does not empower the court to give such a direction subsequent to the execution of the decree. Even the giving of such directions, when dealing with an application for execution, is dependent on the satisfaction of the court that some special cause exists for giving those directions.

anchor.surface_text: The sub-rule does not empower the court to give such a direction subsequent to the execution of the decree. Even the giving of such directions, when dealing with an application for execution, is dependent on the satisfaction of the court that some special cause exists for giving those directions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and contextual reading of Order XLV r.13(2) CPC limits directions to pre-execution stage on special cause.

holdings.text: We find nothing in these provisions which empowered the Court of Sadar Dewani Adalat to demand security from the respondent decree holders or to restrain them from transferring any property over which they had obtained possession in execution of their decree before an appeal was taken to the Privy Council.

anchor.surface_text: We find nothing in these provisions which empowered the Court of Sadar Dewani Adalat to demand security from the respondent decree holders or to restrain them from transferring any property over which they had obtained possession in execution of their decree before an appeal was taken to the Privy Council.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Privy Council and High Court precedents as based on old Bengal Regulations requiring upfront security, unlike CPC's unconditional execution rule.

holdings.text: No occasion for the exercise of any inherent power can arise when the High Court itself does not give any such directions and had not been asked by the judgment-debtor appellant to stay the execution of the decree. To exercise any such inherent power would be not for the prevention of the abuse of the process of the Court but may be to encourage it

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inherent powers under SCR O.XLV r.5 preserved but not applicable post-execution as statutory scheme exhaustive and exercise would encourage judgment-debtor delay.

holdings.text: Any transfers of the property in suit made by the respondents- decree holders during the pendency of the appeal would be subject to the law of lis pendens.

anchor.surface_text: Any transfers of the property in suit made by the respondents- decree holders during the pendency of the appeal would be subject to the law of lis pendens.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of lis pendens doctrine protects appellant's interests without need for restraints.
